generif.text: We report herein the identification of PDCD10 (programmed cell death 10) as the CCM3 gene.
KRIT1, Malcavernin, and PDCD10 are differentially expressed in cerebral venous malformations and cerebral cavernous malformations
Mutations in apoptosis-related gene, PDCD10, cause cerebral cavernous malformation 3.
Sequence analysis of PDCD10 in a panel of 29 probands lacking Krit1 and MGC4607 mutations revealed only three mutations.

The authors screened the PCDC10 gene in 15 families that did not have a CCM1 or CCM2 mutation. Only two novel mutations were found, suggesting that mutations in this gene may only account for a small percentage of CCM familial cases.

Five percent of patients with familial cerebral cavernomas have retinal cavernomas. These lesions are clinically asymptomatic. They can be associated with any of the 3 cerebral cavernous malformation genes.
intergenic region of the head-to-head PDCD10-SERPINI1 gene pair provides an interesting and informative example of a complex regulatory system

Results show that PDCD10 modulation of ERK signaling is mediated by MST4, and that PDCD10 may be a regulatory adaptor necessary for MST4 function, suggesting a link between cerebral cavernous malformation and the ERK-MAPK cascade via PDCD10/MST4.

CCM3 (PDCD10) coprecipitates and colocalizes with CCM2. CCM3 directly binds to serine/threonine kinase 25 (STK25, YSK1, SOK1) and the phosphatase domain of Fas-associated phosphatase-1 (FAP-1, PTPN13, PTP-Bas, PTP-BL).
To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of an association between a mutation in the PDCD10 gene and spinal cavernous malformations.

data are in agreement with a loss-of-function mechanism for CCM mutations, uncover an N-terminal CCM2 domain required for CCM1 binding, and demonstrate full-length CCM2 as the essential core protein in the CCM1/CCM2/CCM3 complex
Biallelic germline and somatic mutations were identified in CCM1, CCM2 or PDCD10 from all forms of inherited cerebral cavernous malformations.
Complete localized loss of either CCM1, CCM2 or CCM3 protein expression depend on the inherited mutation in cerebral cavernous malformations.

Multiplex Ligation-dependent Probe Amplification analysis integrates the consecutive sequence analysis of the 3 genes (Krit1/CCM1, MGC4607/CCM2, and PDCD10/CCM3) known to be responsible for cerebral cavernous malformation lesions.
CCM3 is both necessary and sufficient to induce apoptosis in vitro in well-defined cell culture systems
The newly mapped STK25 and MST4 interaction domain within the CCM3 protein plays a crucial role for vascular development in zebrafish.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
We report multiple dural lesions mimicking meningiomas in patients with CCM3/PDCD10 mutations.
CCM3 protein contributes to vasculogenesis and angiogenesis in human placenta.
CCM3 is located on the Golgi apparatus, forming a complex with proteins of the germinal center kinase III (GCKIII) family and GM130, a Golgi-resident protein.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Genetic variations could interfere with the proper CCM1/CCM2/CCM3 protein complex, thus explaining the observed clinical variability in cerebral cavernous malformations in a large family.
Observational study of gene-disease association and gene-gene interaction. (HuGE Navigator)
CCM3 is a cerebral cavernous malformation protein critical for vascular integrity
In cultured human endothelial cells, CCM3 and STK25 regulated barrier function in a manner similar to CCM2, and STKs negatively regulated Rho by directly activating moesin.
A novel large CCM3 deletion is identified with typical magnetic resonance imaging in a patient and her daughter.
Study propose that the Cerebral cavernous malformations protein complex functions in the PI3K signaling pathway through the interaction between PDCD10 and PtdIns(3,4,5)P3.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
The crystal structure of human PDCD10 complexed with inositol-(1,3,4,5)-tetrakisphosphate has been determined at 2.3A resolution.
PDCD10 can form complexes with other members of the CCM family, including CCM2, a key mediator of receptor tyrosine kinase-dependent cell death in neuroblastic tumors.
adenoviral CCM3 expression inhibits endothelial cell migration, proliferation, and tube formation while downregulation of endogenous CCM3 results in increased formation of tube-like structures
Among familial cases of Cerebral cavernous malformations 67% had a mutation in CCM1, 5.5% in CCM2, and 5.5% in CCM3
PDCD10/CCM3 acts as a critical regulator of neuronal survival during development
the crystal structures of CCM3 in complex with three different leucine-aspartate repeat (LD) motifs (LD1, LD2, and LD4) from the scaffolding protein paxillin
role of CCM3 and ezrin/radixin/moesin family of proteins in cell's response to oxidative stress
PDCD10 might be a regulatory adaptor required for STK25 functions, which differ distinctly depending on the redox status of the cells that may be potentially related to tumor progression.
crystal of the CCM3-MST4 C-terminal domain complex belonged to space group P4(1)2(1)2 or P4(3)2(1)2, with unit-cell parameters a = 69.10, b = 69.10, c = 117.57 A
Loss of CCM3 impairs DLL4-Notch signalling and is associated with impaired endothelial angiogenesis and inherited cerebral cavernous malformations.
CCM3 mutations are associated with cerebral cavernous malformation in some Japanese patients.
CCM3 forms a stable complex with MST4 in vivo to promote cell proliferation and migration synergistically in a manner dependent on MST4 kinase activity.
DNA sequencing and deletion/duplication testing of the CCM1, CCM2, and CCM3 genes in the proband revealed a CCM1 c.601CNG mutation.
The identification of other four new mutations in 40 sporadic patients with either single or multiple cerebral cavernous malformations, is reported.
Prevalence, frequency and characterization of CCM1, CCM2 and CCM3 variants in cerebral cavernous malformation Spanish patients.

Study shows that PDCD10 mutations result in vascular permeability mediated by ROCK activity and a particularly severe clinical phenotype of patients and mouse model for cerebral cavernous malformation disease.

DNA mutational analysis in 87 Italian affected individuals with Cerebral cavernous malformations identified mutations in over 97.7% of cases, and PDCD10/CCM3 mutations account for 13.1% four of which already known and four novel ones.
Identification of genetic variants in the CCM3/PDCD10 gene which are critical indicators of cerebral cavernous malformations in humans.
Our results suggest that MST4, STK25 and PDCD10 are upregulated in prostate cancer and may play roles in prostate tumorigenesis.
Results broaden our knowledge on the mechanisms by which CCM3 deficiency results in disease and open new avenues of research into both CCM3 and senescence biology.
both CCM2 and CCM3 are required for normal endothelial cell network formation.
miR-181b was upregulated by hypoxia in retinoblastoma in an HIF-1a-independent manner.  Additionally, miR-181b exerts its angiogenic function, at least in part, by inhibiting PDCD10 and GATA6.

A novel CCM3 missense mutation (c.422T>G) detected in 2 Greek brothers with cerebral cavernous malformations causes a loss of function in Pdcd10 protein due to its localization in the 8th helix. It affects Leu141. It may play a role in angiogenesis.
A causative mutation in the PDCD10 gene (p.Gln112PhefsX13) was identified in an Italian family with cerebral cavernous malformations associated with meningioma.
Loss of endothelial programmed cell death 10 activates glioblastoma cells and promotes tumor growth.

Studies suggest that the 3 proteins of the Cerebral Cavernous Malformations (CCM) complex KRIT1/CCM1, CCM2/malcavernin and CCM3/PDCD10 not only require one another for reciprocal stabilization, but also act as a platform for signal transduction.
Study highlights the potential role of CCM3 in regulating tight junction complex organization and brain endothelial barrier permeability through CCM3-ERK1/2-cortactin cross-talk
We report for the first time that PDCD10 expression is downregulated in GBM, which is associated with the activation of Akt signaling protein
The proto-oncogene PDCD10 is direct target of miR-103 that can suppress Prostate cancer proliferation and migration by down-regulating the PDCD10.
Inhibition of Notch and activation of VEGF/p38 signaling were involved in miR-425-5p/CCM3 mediated inhibition of angiogenesis by sodium arsenite.
CCM3 restrains ANGPT2 release from endothelial cells and maintains endothelial junctions. CCM3 depletion leads to increased ANGPT2 release.
Data indicated that rs9853967 and rs11714980 polymorphisms in CCM3 and SERPINI1respectively could be associated with a protective role in cerebral cavernous malformations disease.
The identified endothelial signalling pathway of CCM3-DLL4/Notch-EphB4-Erk1/2 may provide an insight into mechanism of CCM3-ablation-mediated angiogenesis.
We showed that overexpression of PDCD10 significantly inhibited miR-103-induced inhibition of cell proliferation, increased apoptosis, and decreased invasion and migration in A549 cells.

Case-control study to investigate the possible association of others polymorphisms (c.485+65 C/G, c.989+63 C/G, c.1980 A/G in CCM1 gene, c.472+127 C/T in CCM2 and c.150 G/A in CCM3) with cerebral cavernous malformations. The five polymorphisms were characterized in 64 sporadic patients and in 90 healthy controls by ASO-PCR. Results suggest that some polymorphisms in CCM genes could play an important role in the disease.
Over-expression of PDCD10 in HeLa cells increased the resistance to doxorubicin.

showed a population-specific mutational and clinical spectrum of multiple CCMs. These findings broaden the mutational spectrum in CCMs and highlight the importance of screening for deletions in the CCM genes in patients with multiple CCMs

Study identified a novel large deletion in PDCD10 gene in patients with cerebral cavernous malformation (CCM) and explored its cellular effect which associated with significant reduction of interactions between KRIT1 and CCM2, and impaired autophagy process.

Data show that PDCD10 expression levels are high in bladder cancer (BC) tissues and seems to correlate with worse prognosis. PDCD10 is directly modulated by miR26a/miR26b as a target in BC cells. PDCD10 promotes BC cell proliferation in vitro and growth and progression of BC in vivo.
Loss of programmed cell death 10 activates tumor cells and leads to temozolomide-resistance in glioblastoma, suggesting PDCD10 as a potential target for glioblastoma therapy.
Distinct cellular roles for PDCD10 define a gut-brain axis in cerebral cavernous malformation.
Emerging roles of CCM genes during tumorigenesis with potential application as novel biomarkers across major types of cancers.
CircSMARCA5 Facilitates the Progression of Prostate Cancer Through miR-432/PDCD10 Axis.
Down-regulated miR-495 can target programmed cell death 10 in ankylosing spondylitis.
Non-canonical signaling pathway of SNAI2 induces EMT in ovarian cancer cells by suppressing miR-222-3p transcription and upregulating PDCD10.
Improving clinical interpretation of five KRIT1 and PDCD10 intronic variants.
Programmed Cell Death 10 Mediated CXCL2-CXCR2 Signaling in Regulating Tumor-Associated Microglia/Macrophages Recruitment in Glioblastoma.
CCM3 is a gatekeeper in focal adhesions regulating mechanotransduction and YAP/TAZ signalling.
Programmed cell death 10 promotes metastasis and epithelial-mesenchymal transition of hepatocellular carcinoma via PP2Ac-mediated YAP activation.
PDCD10 promotes proliferation, migration, and invasion of osteosarcoma by inhibiting apoptosis and activating EMT pathway.
PDCD10 promotes the aggressive behaviors of pituitary adenomas by up-regulating CXCR2 and activating downstream AKT/ERK signaling.
Comprehensive CCM3 Mutational Analysis in Two Patients with Syndromic Cerebral Cavernous Malformation.
Programmed cell death 10 can be used as a potential biomarker for ankylosing spondylitis diagnosis and treatment.
Knockdown of CCM3 promotes angiogenesis through activation and nuclear translocation of YAP/TAZ.
Study on the role of CCM3 gene and lead exposure induced neurotoxicity through neurovascular units.

interpro.desc: Programmed cell death protein 10, dimerisation domain superfamily
Programmed cell death protein 10, dimerisation domain

name: programmed cell death 10

pid.name: Validated targets of C-MYC transcriptional activation

summary: This gene encodes an evolutionarily conserved protein associated with cell apoptosis. The protein interacts with the serine/threonine protein kinase MST4 to modulate the extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) pathway. It also interacts with and is phosphoryated by serine/threonine kinase 25, and is thought to function in a signaling pathway essential for vascular developent. Mutations in this gene are one cause of cerebral cavernous malformations, which are vascular malformations that cause seizures and cerebral hemorrhages. Multiple alternatively spliced variants, encoding the same protein, have been identified. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
